From these images, we can see a lot of things. Note: all of these are theories.

Around the time Kerbin was formed, an asteroid the size of Duna impacted Kerbin. Causing Kerbin to have an iron core and a stable magnetic field. Part of the debris from the impact forge to form the mÃƒÂ¼n.

Around some million years after that, several giant asteroids impacted the MÃƒÂ¼n's equator causing debris to collect on the MÃƒÂ¼n's north and south poles. The mÃƒÂ¼n's crust has not fully solidified that time.

When the mun's crust solifies, smaller asteroids bombarded the mÃƒÂ¼n's surface. One big impact occurred on the mÃƒÂ¼n's north pole. Soon, magma starts to leak out from the mantle, forming the many canyons that are seen.

In 2012, Munoliths and MÃƒÂ¼n archs start to appear for a reason that could be explained geographically.

[ATTACH=CONFIG]33703[/ATTACH]

[ATTACH=CONFIG]33704[/ATTACH]

From these images, we can see a lot of things. Note: all of these are theories.

Around the time Kerbin was formed, an asteroid the size of Duna impacted Kerbin. Causing Kerbin to have an iron core and a stable magnetic field. Part of the debris from the impact forge to form the mÃƒÂ¼n.

Around some million years after that, several giant asteroids impacted the MÃƒÂ¼n's equator causing debris to collect on the MÃƒÂ¼n's north and south poles. The mÃƒÂ¼n's crust has not fully solidified that time.

When the mun's crust solifies, smaller asteroids bombarded the mÃƒÂ¼n's surface. One big impact occurred on the mÃƒÂ¼n's north pole. Soon, magma starts to leak out from the mantle, forming the many canyons that are seen.

In 2012, Munoliths and MÃƒÂ¼n archs start to appear for a reason that could be explained geographically.

What about Minmus?

Exact same process.

Except with an Ike sized object.
I submit that it is much more likely that Minmus is a relatively recent capture, an icy body originating elsewhere in the Kerbol system, probably in their equivalent of the Oort cloud or Kuiper belt.

The Kerbol systems shows substantial signs of artificial modification/non-Kerbal intelligent life, making determining any natural geologic history difficult. That said, I'd still like to know why the MÃƒÂ¼n has what looks like water erosion in some craters.

Exact same process.

Except with an Ike sized object.

That would have affected Kerbin's gravity and thus the Mun's trajectory. All life on Kerbin, including the Kerbal Space Administration's workers, would have been killed by the impact. Obviously, no such thing occurred when 0.15 released, so we can conclude that it was not the same thing.

That would have affected Kerbin's gravity and thus the Mun's trajectory. All life on Kerbin, including the Kerbal Space Administration's workers, would have been killed by the impact. Obviously, no such thing occurred when 0.15 released, so we can conclude that it was not the same thing.

It didn't happen when the Mun was released either.
